notes: Some Acartophthalmus species are necrophagous. Acartophthalmus nigrinus are found in woodland habitats on decaying fungi and carrion.

notes: Found in forest litter, moist soil, dung, compost, mud, algae mats, water reservoirs and marshes. Found in water associated, moist substrates, but not submerged. Some live in moist tissues of cacti. Some are important vectors. Some species do not take blood meals. Some larvae consume organic material, microorganisms, and small invertebrates. Will bite humans. Feed on a range of vertebrates including cattle, horses, donkeys, pigs and birds.

notes: Found in tidal coves, freshwater pools, lakes, sandy bottoms of waterbodies, flowing water, dung and in swampy areas near aquatic plants. Important for detritus processing and organic matter recycling. Different populations feed on different levels of detritus versus algae. Larvae are grazers or filter feeders.

references: Manual of Nearctic Diptera | The Diptera families of British Columbia | The Frit Flies (Chloropidae, Diptera) of Fennoscandia and Denmark (http://doi.org/10.1163/9789004190665) | Family Chloropidae (http://doi.org/10.11646/zootaxa.4122.1.60) | Biology and Immature Stages of Chlorops certimus and Epichlorops exilis (Diptera: Chloropidae), Stem-Borers of Wetland Sedges | Grass-fly Larvae (Diptera, Chloropidae): Diversity, Habitats, and Feeding Specializations (https://doi.org/10.1134/S001387381404006X) | Plant Parasites of Europe (https://bladmineerders.nl/) | Chloropid flies (Diptera, Chloropidae) associated with pitcher plants in North America (https://doi.org/10.7717/peerj.4491)

notes: Larvae have various food habits. Many damage cereals and grasses. Some adults visit flowers and feed on plant secretions and honeydew, others feed at body openings. Larvae develop in stems and decaying organic matter. Found in grasslands, meadows, swamps, sandy coasts, and wetlands.
references: Manual of Nearctic Diptera | The Diptera families of British Columbia | The Frit Flies (Chloropidae, Diptera) of Fennoscandia and Denmark (http://doi.org/10.1163/9789004190665) | Family Chloropidae (http://doi.org/10.11646/zootaxa.4122.1.60) | Biology and Immature Stages of Chlorops certimus and Epichlorops exilis (Diptera: Chloropidae), Stem-Borers of Wetland Sedges | Grass-fly Larvae (Diptera, Chloropidae): Diversity, Habitats, and Feeding Specializations (https://doi.org/10.1134/S001387381404006X)

notes: Some are found on sandy beaches. Larvae feed on the shoots and stems of grasses. Some species are saprophagous or predaceous.
references: Manual of Nearctic Diptera | The Diptera families of British Columbia | The Frit Flies (Chloropidae, Diptera) of Fennoscandia and Denmark (http://doi.org/10.1163/9789004190665) | Family Chloropidae (http://doi.org/10.11646/zootaxa.4122.1.60) | Biology and Immature Stages of Chlorops certimus and Epichlorops exilis (Diptera: Chloropidae), Stem-Borers of Wetland Sedges | Grass-fly Larvae (Diptera, Chloropidae): Diversity, Habitats, and Feeding Specializations (https://doi.org/10.1134/S001387381404006X) | Plant Parasites of Europe (https://bladmineerders.nl/)

notes: Larvae have various food habits. Many damage cereals and grasses. Some adults visit flowers and feed on plant secretions and honeydew, others feed at body openings. Larvae develop in stems and decaying organic matter. Found in grasslands, meadows, swamps, sandy coasts, and wetlands.
references: Manual of Nearctic Diptera | The Diptera families of British Columbia | The Frit Flies (Chloropidae, Diptera) of Fennoscandia and Denmark (http://doi.org/10.1163/9789004190665) | Family Chloropidae (http://doi.org/10.11646/zootaxa.4122.1.60) | Biology and Immature Stages of Chlorops certimus and Epichlorops exilis (Diptera: Chloropidae), Stem-Borers of Wetland Sedges | Grass-fly Larvae (Diptera, Chloropidae): Diversity, Habitats, and Feeding Specializations (https://doi.org/10.1134/S001387381404006X)

notes: Some have been reared from grasses but are scavengers. Some are Leaf/Root/Stem Feeding and feed on stems of wetland monocots. Larvae can develop from rotting vegetation, decaying wood and leaf mold. Found in nests of animals, dung, and dead tissues of plants.

notes: Some have been reared from grasses but are scavengers. Some are Leaf/Root/Stem Feeding and feed on stems of wetland monocots. Larvae can develop from rotting vegetation, decaying wood and leaf mold. Found in nests of animals, dung, and dead tissues of plants.

notes: Feed on roots and stems of grasses. Some species are scavengers.

notes: Adults feed around the eyes and wounds of animals. They do not bite, but use their mouthparts to feed on scabs and scar tissue. Larvae feed on rotten vegetation and dung, as well as on living plants.
references: Eye Gnat (Liohippelates, Diptera: Chloropidae) Biology, Ecology, and Management: Past, Present, and future (https://doi.org/10.1093/jipm/pmac015) | Grass-fly Larvae (Diptera, Chloropidae): Diversity, Habitats, and Feeding Specializations (https://doi.org/10.1134/S001387381404006X)

notes: Larvae have various food habits. Many damage cereals and grasses. Some adults visit flowers and feed on plant secretions and honeydew, others feed at body openings. Larvae develop in stems and decaying organic matter. Found in grasslands, meadows, swamps, sandy coasts, and wetlands.

notes: Larvae damage crops and feed on shoots and stems. Feed on a variety of plants including oats, wheat, balrey, and grassess. Most species are phytophagous, but some are not. Adults visit flowers.

notes: Found in bogs. Larvae feed on shoots and stems of grasses. Some species develop in dead tissues of plants and are saprophagous.

notes: Larvae are leaf mining on aquatic plants. Used as a biological control. Adults prey on small insects. Adults also feed on yeast, fungi, bacteria, nectar and leaves.

Royle (Hydrocharitaceae) growing conditions and nutrient content on the performance of a leaf-mining fly, Hydrellia purcelli Deeming (Diptera: Ephydridae) (https://doi.org/10.1080/09583157.2018.1441370) | Notes on Shore Flies (Diptera: Ephydridae) from Finland and north-western Russia (https://doi.org/10.3897/BDJ.3.e4701)

notes: Found in aquatic and semiaquatic habitats. Found in marshes, shores, tide pools, ponds, and muddy margins of freshwater. Larvae are filter feeding and feed on bacteria, algae and yeasts. Some larvae feed on excrement and some are leaf mining. Adults feed on algae and microorganisms. Adults are generalists and larvae are more specialized.
references: Manual of Nearctic Diptera | The Diptera families of British Columbia | Taxonomy of the genus Scatella Robineau-Desvoidy (Diptera: Ephydridae) in Korea (https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1748-5967.2006.00036.x) | Freshwater Invertebrates in Central Europe: True Flies – Diptera (https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-7091-1547-3_22) | A Multivariate Analysis of Similarity in Shore Fly Habitats (Diptera: Ephydridae) | Diversity of Shore Flies (Diptera: Ephydridae) in Inland Freshwater Habitats

notes: Found in aquatic and semiaquatic habitats. Found in marshes, shores, tide pools, ponds, and muddy margins of freshwater. Larvae are filter feeding and feed on bacteria, algae and yeasts. Some larvae feed on excrement and some are leaf mining. Adults feed on algae and microorganisms. Adults are generalists and larvae are more specialized.
references: Manual of Nearctic Diptera | The Diptera families of British Columbia | Taxonomy of the genus Scatella Robineau-Desvoidy (Diptera: Ephydridae) in Korea (https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1748-5967.2006.00036.x) | Freshwater Invertebrates in Central Europe: True Flies – Diptera (https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-7091-1547-3_22) | A Multivariate Analysis of Similarity in Shore Fly Habitats (Diptera: Ephydridae) | Diversity of Shore Flies (Diptera: Ephydridae) in Inland Freshwater Habitats

notes: Eggs are laid in topsoil and on wet surfaces that contain algae. Found in greenhouses and in muddy and marshy areas around lakes, ponds, rivers and streams. Adults feed on unicellular algae. Larvae feed on bacteria, yeasts, diatoms, and flagellates.
references: Susceptibility of shore fly Scatella stagnalis to five entomopathogenic nematode strains in bioassays (https://doi.org/10.1007/s10526-006-9047-z) | Geographic Variation in Scatella stagnalis (Diptera: Ephydridae) (https://doi.org/10.1093/aesa/70.4.511)

notes: Breed in dung, rotting wood and fungi.
references: Diptera as predators and parasitoids of terrestrial gastropods, with emphasis on Phoridae, Calliphoridae, Sarcophagidae, Muscidae and Fanniidae (https://doi.org/10.1079/9780851993195.0085) | A taxonomic revision of the genus Fannia Robineau-Desvoidy (Diptera: Fanniidae) from Korea (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.japb.2023.03.005) | New Species of Soldier Fly—Sargus bipunctatus (Scopoli, 1763) (Diptera: Stratiomyidae), Recorded from a Human Corpse in Europe—A Case Report (https://doi.org/10.3390/insects12040302) | Life History and Seasonal Abundance of Fannia benjamini Complex (Diptera: Muscidae) in Southern California (https://doi.org/10.1603/0022-2585(2006)043[0192:LHASAO]2.0.CO;2) | Laboratory Colonization, Life History Observations, and Desiccation Tolerance of the Canyon Fly Fannia conspicua (Diptera: Fanniidae) (https://doi.org/10.1093/jme/tjv042) | Freshwater Invertebrates in Central Europe: True Flies – Diptera (https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-7091-1547-3_22) | First record of Fannia leucosticta (Meigen) (Diptera: Fanniidae) breeding in human corpses (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.forsciint.2013.03.022) | Evaluation of ammonia, human sweat, and bovine blood as attractants for the female canyon fly, Fannia conspicua (Diptera: Muscidae), in southern California (https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1948-7134.2011.00140.x) | Sensitivity analysis, molecular systematics and natural history evolution of Scathophagidae (Diptera: Cyclorrhapha: Calyptratae) (https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1096-0031.2006.00131.x) | Complete tribal sampling reveals basal split in Muscidae (Diptera), confirms saprophagy as ancestral feeding mode, and reveals an evolutionary correlation between instar numbers and carnivory (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ympev.2014.05.027)

notes: Adults feed on sap, honeydew, nectar and rotting fruits and vegetables. Some adults feed on blood (without biting), sweat, tears, and other secretions. Larvae feed on decaying leaves and dung. Have been observed on corpses. Develop in rotting plant material and fungi, decaying animals and dung. Also found in brooks and swamps.

notes: Found in apple orchards and onion fields. Lay eggs in soil. Predators of Diptera and various pest species. Larvae feed on earthworms.

notes: Live in water under stones, moss and algae. Found in springs, waterfalls, lakes and rivers. Feed on Chrionomidae and Simuliidae.

notes: Feed on sweat, mucus and blood, as well as flowers. Larvae develop in dung.
references: A Catalogue of the Muscidae (Diptera) of the Neotropical Region | A new species of the genus Morellia Robineau-Desvoidy (Diptera: Muscidae) from Yunnan, China, with analysis of available DNA barcoding sequences (https://doi.org/10.2478/s11756-018-0134-2) | Diptera as predators and parasitoids of terrestrial gastropods, with emphasis on Phoridae, Calliphoridae, Sarcophagidae, Muscidae and Fanniidae (https://doi.org/10.1079/9780851993195.0085) | Complete tribal sampling reveals basal split in Muscidae (Diptera), confirms saprophagy as ancestral feeding mode, and reveals an evolutionary correlation between instar numbers and carnivory (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ympev.2014.05.027)

notes: Breeds in dung. Feeds on fluids and blood from cattle and people, as well as fluids from dung. Larvae feed on bacteria, yeast and organic particles.

notes: Found in hay bales, dung and rotting vegetation. Feed on blood and bite cattle, people and other animals. Also feed on pollen and nectar.

notes: Larvae can also be aquatic. Found in bogs and moist places with rotten plants. Larvae can also be predaceous. Adults found on dung and flowers.

notes: Bites various birds and mammals such as humans, cows, horses, mules, foxes, minks, ducks, rabbits, lynx, caribou and turkeys. Larvae feed on diatoms, algae and bacteria. Some species do not bite. Some species are predaceous. Found in a wide range of aquatic habitats such as streams and rivers.

notes: Larvae are found on alive or decaying plants. Larvae are mostly phytophagous or saprophagous. Adults visit flowers and feed on nectar. Found in habitats such as bogs, forests and meadows.

notes: Some larvae of Anthomyzidae are found in grass stems, but they are likely saprophagous instead of phytophagous. Larvae feed on rotting plants. Some Anthomyza are leaf/root/stem feeding. Some are found in damp places in forests, grasslands, wetlands, or marshes.

notes: Found in forest litter, moist soil, dung, compost, mud, algae mats, water reservoirs and marshes. Found in water associated, moist substrates, but not submerged. Some live in moist tissues of cacti. Some are important vectors. Some species do not take blood meals. Some larvae consume organic material, microorganisms, and small invertebrates. Will bite humans. Feed on a range of vertebrates including cattle, horses, donkeys, pigs and birds.

references: Manual of Nearctic Diptera | The Diptera families of British Columbia | Biting midges of Egypt (Diptera: Ceratopogonidae) (https://doi.org/10.3897/BDJ.8.e52357) | Ultrastructural studies on the midgut of biting midge Forcipomyia nigra (Winnertz) (Diptera: Ceratopogonidae) (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.micron.2014.11.003) | Freshwater Invertebrates in Central Europe: True Flies – Diptera (https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-7091-1547-3_22) | Forcipomyia (Microhelea) Eriophora (Williston) (Diptera: Ceratopogonidae) an Ectoparasite of Larval Anaea troglodyta floridalis (Nymphalidae) (https://doi.org/10.18473/lepi.v66i4.a9) | New Host Records of the Ectoparasitic Biting Midge Forcipomyia (Trichohelea) pectinunguis (Diptera: Ceratopogonidae) on Adult Geometrid Moths (Lepidoptera: Geometridae) (https://doi.org/10.2317/0511.15.1) | A new species of Forcipomyia (Diptera: Ceratopogonidae) ectoparasitic on butterflies in New Guinea (https://doi.org/10.1080/00222938600770411) | Morphological adaptations of the mouthparts to the ectoparasitic lifestyle of the biting midge Forcipomyia paludis (Diptera: Ceratopogonidae), specialized in Odonata (https://doi.org/10.1007/s00435-022-00564-6) |

notes: Feed on Nematocera and Ephemeroptera. Most Ceratopogoninae are predaceous but some filter feed.

Part I. notes: Lake dwelling. Younger instars feed on phytoplankton. Older larvae feed on zooplankton. Feed on copepods, cladocerans, and daphniids.
references: Impact of Chaoborus flavicans-Predation on the Zooplankton in a Mesotrophic Lake – a Three Year Study (https://doi.org/10.1002/iroh.201011253) | Feeding efficiency of Chaoborus flavicans (Insecta, Diptera) under turbulent conditions (https://doi.org/10.1007/s10750-013-1670-y) | Chaoborus flavicans Meigen (Diptera, Chaoboridae) is a complex of lake and pond dwelling species: a revision (https://doi.org/10.11646/zootaxa.4927.2.1) | Density- and Size-Dependent Winter Mortality and Growth of Late Chaoborus flavicans Larvae (https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0075839)

notes: Feed on phytoplankton, rotifers and crustaceans.
references: Seasonal changes in the diel vertical migration of Chaoborus punctipennis larval instars (https://doi.org/10.1139/cjfas-2013-0440) | Differential use of food resources by the instars of Chaoborus punctipennis (https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1365-2427.1988.tb00346.x) | Chaoborus flavicans Meigen (Diptera, Chaoboridae) is a complex of lake and pond dwelling species: a revision (https://doi.org/10.11646/zootaxa.4927.2.1) | Feeding efficiency of Chaoborus flavicans (Insecta, Diptera) under turbulent conditions (https://doi.org/10.1007/s10750-013-1670-y) | Density- and Size-Dependent Winter Mortality and Growth of Late Chaoborus flavicans Larvae (https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0075839) | Impact of Chaoborus flavicans-Predation on the Zooplankton in a Mesotrophic Lake – a Three Year Study (https://doi.org/10.1002/iroh.201011253)

notes: Found in tidal coves, freshwater pools, lakes, sandy bottoms of waterbodies, flowing water, dung and in swampy areas near aquatic plants. Important for detritus processing and organic matter recycling. Different populations feed on different levels of detritus versus algae. Larvae are grazers or filter feeders.

notes: Found in tidal coves, freshwater pools, lakes, sandy bottoms of waterbodies, flowing water, dung and in swampy areas near aquatic plants. Important for detritus processing and organic matter recycling. Different populations feed on different levels of detritus versus algae. Larvae are grazers or filter feeders.

traitValue: Leaf/Root/Stem Feeding and Detritus and Algae Feeding
notes: Found in mosses, margins of springs, ditches, streams, pitcher plants, lakes and rock pools. Some are also found in terrestrial habitats. Larvae mine leaves and feed on algae. Some are saprophagous.

notes: Larvae have various food habits. Many damage cereals and grasses. Some adults visit flowers and feed on plant secretions and honeydew, others feed at body openings. Larvae develop in stems and decaying organic matter. Found in grasslands, meadows, swamps, sandy coasts, and wetlands.

notes: Adults feed around the eyes and wounds of animals. They do not bite, but use their mouthparts to feed on scabs and scar tissue. Larvae feed on rotten vegetation and dung, as well as on living plants.

notes: Larvae are leaf mining on aquatic plants. Used as a biological control. Adults prey on small insects. Adults also feed on yeast, fungi, bacteria, nectar and leaves.
references: Manual of Nearctic Diptera | Plant Parasites of Europe (https://bladmineerders.nl/) | The Diptera families of British Columbia | Biology and preliminary host range of a Korean leaf-mining Hydrellia sp. (Diptera: Ephydridae) rejected as a potential biological control agent for monoecious Hydrilla verticillata in the United States (https://doi.org/10.1080/09583157.2020.1853051) | A new species of Hydrellia (Diptera: Ephydridae) mining Hydrilla verticillata (Hydrocharitaceae) leaves in Singapore (https://doi-org/10.1111/aen.12193) | Responses of adult Hydrellia lagarosiphon to a revised diet: implications for life cycle studies and laboratory culturing techniques (https://doi.org/10.1111/eea.12350) | Hydrellia spp. [Diptera : Ephydridae] attacking Hydrilla verticillata in south india (https://doi.org/10.1007/BF02374795) | Biology and ecology of Brazilian elodea (Egeria densa) and its specific herbivore, Hydrellia sp., in Argentina (https://doi.org/10.1007/s10526-012-9475-x) | Laboratory biology and host range of Hydrellia balciunasi [Diptera : Ephydridae] (https://doi.org/10.1007/BF02374440) | First Nearctic Record of Hydrellia albilabris (Meigen) (Diptera: Ephydridae), a Leafminer of Duckweed (Araceae: Lemnoideae), with Comments on Related Species (https://doi.org/10.4289/0013-8797.121.2.160) | Risk assessment of the host range of Hydrellia lagarosiphon for the biological control of Lagarosiphon major in Ireland (https://doi.org/10.1080/09583157.2023.2215993) | Hydrellia lagarosiphon Deeming (Diptera: Ephydridae), a potential biological control agent for the submerged aquatic weed, Lagarosiphon major (Ridl.) Moss ex Wager (Hydrocharitaceae) (https://doi.org/10.4001/003.021.0118) | Risk assessment to interpret the physiological host range of Hydrellia egeriae, a biocontrol agent for Egeria densa (https://doi.org/10.1007/s10526-019-09942-4) | Effects of Hydrilla verticillata (L.f.) Royle (Hydrocharitaceae) growing conditions and nutrient content on the performance of a leaf-mining fly, Hydrellia purcelli Deeming (Diptera: Ephydridae) (https://doi.org/10.1080/09583157.2018.1441370) | Notes on Shore Flies (Diptera: Ephydridae) from Finland and north-western Russia (https://doi.org/10.3897/BDJ.3.e4701)

notes: Found in aquatic and semiaquatic habitats. Found in marshes, shores, tide pools, ponds, and muddy margins of freshwater. Larvae are filter feeding and feed on bacteria, algae and yeasts. Some larvae feed on excrement and some are leaf mining. Adults feed on algae and microorganisms. Adults are generalists and larvae are more specialized.
references: Manual of Nearctic Diptera | The Diptera families of British Columbia | Taxonomy of the genus Scatella Robineau-Desvoidy (Diptera: Ephydridae) in Korea (https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1748-5967.2006.00036.x) | Freshwater Invertebrates in Central Europe: True Flies – Diptera (https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-7091-1547-3_22) | A Multivariate Analysis of Similarity in Shore Fly Habitats (Diptera: Ephydridae) | Diversity of Shore Flies (Diptera: Ephydridae) in Inland Freshwater Habitats

notes: Found in aquatic and semiaquatic habitats. Found in marshes, shores, tide pools, ponds, and muddy margins of freshwater. Larvae are filter feeding and feed on bacteria, algae and yeasts. Some larvae feed on excrement and some are leaf mining. Adults feed on algae and microorganisms. Adults are generalists and larvae are more specialized.
references: Manual of Nearctic Diptera | The Diptera families of British Columbia | Taxonomy of the genus Scatella Robineau-Desvoidy (Diptera: Ephydridae) in Korea (https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1748-5967.2006.00036.x) | Freshwater Invertebrates in Central Europe: True Flies – Diptera (https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-7091-1547-3_22) | A Multivariate Analysis of Similarity in Shore Fly Habitats (Diptera: Ephydridae) | Diversity of Shore Flies (Diptera: Ephydridae) in Inland Freshwater Habitats

notes: Eggs are laid in topsoil and on wet surfaces that contain algae. Found in greenhouses and in muddy and marshy areas around lakes, ponds, rivers and streams. Adults feed on unicellular algae. Larvae feed on bacteria, yeasts, diatoms, and flagellates.
references: Susceptibility of shore fly Scatella stagnalis to five entomopathogenic nematode strains in bioassays (https://doi.org/10.1007/s10526-006-9047-z) | Geographic Variation in Scatella stagnalis (Diptera: Ephydridae) (https://doi.org/10.1093/aesa/70.4.511)

notes: Breed in dung, rotting wood and fungi.
references: Diptera as predators and parasitoids of terrestrial gastropods, with emphasis on Phoridae, Calliphoridae, Sarcophagidae, Muscidae and Fanniidae (https://doi.org/10.1079/9780851993195.0085) | A taxonomic revision of the genus Fannia Robineau-Desvoidy (Diptera: Fanniidae) from Korea (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.japb.2023.03.005) | New Species of Soldier Fly—Sargus bipunctatus (Scopoli, 1763) (Diptera: Stratiomyidae), Recorded from a Human Corpse in Europe—A Case Report (https://doi.org/10.3390/insects12040302) | Life History and Seasonal Abundance of Fannia benjamini Complex (Diptera: Muscidae) in Southern California (https://doi.org/10.1603/0022-2585(2006)043[0192:LHASAO]2.0.CO;2) | Laboratory Colonization, Life History Observations, and Desiccation Tolerance of the Canyon Fly Fannia conspicua (Diptera: Fanniidae) (https://doi.org/10.1093/jme/tjv042) | Freshwater Invertebrates in Central Europe: True Flies – Diptera (https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-7091-1547-3_22) | First record of Fannia leucosticta (Meigen) (Diptera: Fanniidae) breeding in human corpses (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.forsciint.2013.03.022) | Evaluation of ammonia, human sweat, and bovine blood as attractants for the female canyon fly, Fannia conspicua (Diptera: Muscidae), in southern California (https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1948-7134.2011.00140.x) | Sensitivity analysis, molecular systematics and natural history evolution of Scathophagidae (Diptera: Cyclorrhapha: Calyptratae) (https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1096-0031.2006.00131.x) | Complete tribal sampling reveals basal split in Muscidae (Diptera), confirms saprophagy as ancestral feeding mode, and reveals an evolutionary correlation between instar numbers and carnivory (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ympev.2014.05.027)

notes: Adults feed on sap, honeydew, nectar and rotting fruits and vegetables. Some adults feed on blood (without biting), sweat, tears, and other secretions. Larvae feed on decaying leaves and dung. Have been observed on corpses. Develop in rotting plant material and fungi, decaying animals and dung. Also found in brooks and swamps.

notes: Found in dung and on bodies. Adults feed on perspiration, blood and facial secretions. Some larvae filter feed in dung, some are necrophagous, and others are predaceous.

notes: Lay eggs beneath soil surface. Generalist predators. Predators of Diptera, earthworms and various pest species, such as fungus gnats, whiteflies, leaf miners, aphids, leafhoppers, moth flies, shore flies and fruit flies.

notes: Feed on sweat, mucus and blood, as well as flowers. Larvae develop in dung.

notes: Breeds in dung. Feeds on fluids and blood from cattle and people, as well as fluids from dung. Larvae feed on bacteria, yeast and organic particles.

notes: Found in dung. Larvae and adults are coprophagous.
references: Topical treatment of calves with synthetic pyrethroids: effects on the non-target dung fly Neomyia cornicina (Diptera: Muscidae) (https://doi.org/10.1079/BER200079)

notes: Found in hay bales, dung and rotting vegetation. Feed on blood and bite cattle, people and other animals. Also feed on pollen and nectar.
references: The Diptera families of British Columbia | Stable Fly (Diptera: Muscidae)—Biology, Management, and Research Needs (https://doi.org/10.1093/jipm/pmab029) | Pollen from the exoskeletons of stable flies, Stomoxys calcitrans(linnaeus 1758), in Gainesville, Florida, U.S.A. (https://doi.org/10.2113/gspalynol.32.1.77) | Egg-laying decisions based on olfactory cues enhance offspring fitness in Stomoxys calcitrans L. (Diptera: Muscidae) (https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-019-40479-9) | Sensitivity analysis, molecular systematics and natural history evolution of Scathophagidae (Diptera: Cyclorrhapha: Calyptratae) (https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1096-0031.2006.00131.x)

notes: Larvae can also be aquatic. Found in bogs and moist places with rotten plants. Larvae can also be predaceous. Adults found on dung and flowers.

notes: Bites various birds and mammals such as humans, cows, horses, mules, foxes, minks, ducks, rabbits, lynx, caribou and turkeys. Larvae feed on diatoms, algae and bacteria. Some species do not bite. Some species are predaceous. Found in a wide range of aquatic habitats such as streams and rivers.

notes: Found in mud of freshwater ponds, streams and swamps. Feed on blood of humans, livestock and other mammals, as well as nectar and honeydew. Some larvae have fed on bloodworms in a lab setting. Larvae may also feed on plant matter in the mud.
